header.subtitle: From intelligence officer to award-winning novelist

biography.title: Biography
biography.text: Raphaël Jerusalmy was born in Montmartre in 1954. After graduating from both the École Normale Supérieure and the Sorbonne, he served fifteen years in Israeli military intelligence before turning to humanitarian work and, eventually, to the trade of rare books in Tel Aviv. Writing, however, became the through-line of his life: since his explosive 2002 debut *Shalom Tsahal*, he has produced a body of fiction that blends erudition, moral urgency and narrative daring. Of Sephardic origin through his paternal grandmother Sultana, most of whose family members were exterminated at Auschwitz, he is also Russian Ashkenazi through his father, a dealer, craftsman, bookbinder and gilder.

writingPhilosophy.title: Writing Philosophy
writingPhilosophy.text: I write to illuminate the blind spots of history – the places where official archives fall silent and only the imagination can testify.

influences.text: Jerusalmy cites François Villon, Stefan Zweig and modern reportage as touchstones, blending poetic risk with journalistic precision.

items.title: An Incredible Self-Control
items.excerpt: Faced with adversity and the horrors of October 7, 2023, Israel demonstrated exceptional resilience. Neither despair nor barbarism diverted it from its moral dignity.
items.subtitle: An analysis of Israel’s moral fortitude post-October 7, 2023
items.description: In this analytical piece for Tribune Juive, Raphaël Jerusalmy examines how Israel maintained its moral integrity in the aftermath of the horrific events of October 7, 2023, highlighting the unwavering determination of its citizens in the face of terror and adversity.
items.content:
The most striking aspect of Israel’s response to the October 7, 2023 massacres is how its people preserved perfect self-control. Despite the initial shock and the prolonged combat that followed, at no point did the population succumb to despair. They never mirrored the barbarism of their attackers, holding fast to their moral dignity even in those dark, harrowing weeks.

Jewish communities in Israel and the diaspora are reliving painful echoes of a past not so distant. Yet as the ugliness of antisemitism rears its head anew, the resilience with which the Jewish people face it is more admirable than ever. Outrageous statements from certain UN bodies, biased media outlets, or spiteful politicians crash again and again against the rock-solid perseverance of Jewish continuity. Hatred may rise and fall through the centuries, but Israel endures—and its spirit remains unbroken.

The staged theatrics of Hamas during hostage releases, the shameful pro-jihad rallies in free democracies, the spurious accusations, countless boycotts, and the intellectual slurs hurled by celebrities and establishments alike all ultimately disgrace their perpetrators. In contrast, the Jewish people emerge ennobled, strengthened, and proud to preserve their identity and self-respect amid the torrent of hatred.

Of course, Israelis suffer and mourn. Every day brings new names of soldiers killed or wounded, fresh missile alerts, and the agonizing task of explaining violence to young children without instilling terror. Yet each dawn, Israel confronts these challenges—and overcomes them. Though wounded in body and spirit, it refuses to yield an inch. Instead, it forges ahead: creating, inventing, and building—while many nations regress toward darker times.

This struggle demands constant vigilance over anger, resentment, and grief. It calls for immense inner strength to support our families, comfort the bereaved, and stand by the brave hostages and soldiers at the front. I am proud to stand among you. Thanks to your unwavering resilience, we have achieved the only victory that truly matters—the victory of integrity, determination, and tenacity that has sustained us through the ages.

items.title: Israel's True Victory
items.excerpt: By negotiating with Hamas for its hostages, Israel achieves a moral victory that transcends the military stakes of the conflict.
items.subtitle: Editorial on the moral implications of negotiating for hostages
items.description: In this editorial for Tribune Juive, Raphaël Jerusalmy argues that Israel’s negotiations with Hamas for the release of its hostages represent a moral triumph that elevates the sanctity of life above military considerations, reflecting the nation’s deep commitment to its values.
items.content:
Negotiating with a terrorist organization always carries heavy political and psychological costs—but Israel’s recent exchanges with Hamas over hostage release have achieved something far greater than any battlefield gain. By placing the value of human life above all else, Israel has demonstrated that moral courage can outshine military might.

From the outset, officials insisted that every effort be made to bring every man, woman, and child home. This unwavering commitment to negotiation—even under the most trying international scrutiny—sent a clear message: no strategic objective justifies abandoning our own.

Critics decry concessions, but they miss the deeper victory: restoring hope to families held hostage, reaffirming national unity, and reminding the world that Israel’s core strength lies not only in its army, but in its compassion. Each successful release chip­ped away at Hamas’s leverage and bolstered Israel’s moral standing.

The repercussions extend beyond the immediate hostages. By choosing dialogue backed by decisive readiness for action, Israel sets a precedent for how democracies can respond to terror without sacrificing their soul. In the end, this moral triumph may yet prove more enduring than any territorial achievement.

items.title: Palestine, Ecological Nuisance
items.excerpt: The Palestinian Authority is accused of conducting a deliberate policy of environmental degradation in the territories it administers.
items.subtitle: Accusation of environmental sabotage by the Palestinian Authority
items.description: Raphaël Jerusalmy details how the Palestinian Authority’s policies—ranging from sewage dumping and unauthorized landfills to the illicit burning of tires and electronic waste—constitute an “environmental terrorism” that violates Oslo agreements and endangers public health and ecosystems across the region.
items.content:
Environmental protection is not merely a civil concern—it is a matter of security. In this explosive exposé, Raphaël Jerusalmy lays bare how the Palestinian Authority’s systematic mismanagement of waste and natural resources amounts to a form of ecological terrorism.

From the unchecked dumping of raw sewage into the Jordan Valley, to sprawling illegal landfills near delicate aquifers, the damage is both immediate and long-term. Nations that signed the Oslo Accords pledged to uphold environmental standards; instead, vast swathes of farmland and residential areas have been contaminated.

Worse still, the deliberate burning of tires and electronic refuse releases carcinogenic toxins into the air, threatening neighboring communities in both the West Bank and Israel. Years of neglect have transformed once-fertile valleys into blighted zones, forcing local populations to seek costly treatment for respiratory and water-borne diseases.

Jerusalmy calls on international bodies to enforce strict environmental oversight as part of any future agreements. Without accountability, this slow-motion assault on Mother Nature will escalate—eroding not only ecosystems, but the fragile foundations of peace itself.

items.title: Poor Lebanon
items.excerpt: It's a shame to abandon the only country in the Middle East, apart from Israel, that is so close to Western mentality and culture.
items.subtitle: An appeal for international support to rescue Lebanon from isolation and preserve its Western ties
items.description: Raphaël Jerusalmy argues that Lebanon, standing as one of the only Middle Eastern countries culturally aligned with the West, must leverage the U.S.–France axis and the recent maritime gas deal with Israel to overcome economic collapse, dismantle Hezbollah’s stranglehold, and rebuild its sovereignty and stability.
items.content:
Lebanon has long served as a bridge between East and West—a vibrant mosaic of cultures, religions, and traditions. Yet today, economic ruin and political paralysis threaten to pull the country into the abyss.

Hezbollah’s unchecked power, chronic corruption, and an outdated patronage system have hollowed out institutions. The once-bustling ports of Beirut now lie in ruins; power cuts and fuel shortages grip the population daily.

In this article, Raphaël Jerusalmy urges Western partners—most notably France and the United States—to seize the moment created by Lebanon’s recent maritime gas accord with Israel. By offering targeted financial aid tied to structural reforms, they can compel a recalibration of power away from militias and toward the state.

Time is of the essence. Without swift, concerted action, Lebanon risks becoming a failed state—a haven for extremism that would destabilize the entire region. Preserving Lebanon’s Western affinity is not charity; it is strategic necessity.

items.title: October 7th... One Year Later
items.excerpt: One year later, the balance of power has changed. By October 7th next year, in 2025, the Middle East will have been completely remodeled.
items.subtitle: An assessment of shifting power dynamics and future regional transformations
items.description: Raphaël Jerusalmy reflects on how, one year after October 7th, 2023, Israeli defense and intelligence agencies have reasserted their strength even as political divisions persist; he explores the enduring questions facing Israel and the Jewish people—from unity at home and solidarity abroad to the balance between negotiation and military pressure.
items.content:
A year has passed since the brutal onslaught of October 7, 2023—and the Middle East today looks very different. In this reflective essay, Raphaël Jerusalmy examines the transformation of regional power balances.

Israel’s intelligence reconstruction has been swift and ruthless. New cyber-defense capabilities and revamped special-forces brigades now deter would-be aggressors. Yet at home, political infighting over security and judicial reforms continues to test national unity.

Abroad, alliances have shifted: some Arab states, once reticent, now openly collaborate on security matters, while traditional partners press Israel to redouble diplomatic efforts. The lessons of the past year underscore a delicate equilibrium: military preparedness must be coupled with political acumen.

Looking ahead to October 7, 2025, Jerusalmy argues that the region’s fate will hinge on whether leaders choose dialogue or division, reconstruction or retaliation—choices that will echo through generations.

items.title: Anti-Semites, Smile You’re Being Filmed
items.excerpt: In the digital age, technological surveillance becomes a tool in the fight against antisemitism.
items.subtitle: Exploring the use of digital surveillance and IoT in detecting and preventing antisemitic threats
items.description: Raphaël Jerusalmy highlights how specialized Mossad units leverage big data, keyword tracking, and Internet of Things devices to identify and monitor antisemitic individuals worldwide, underscoring both the technological capabilities and the legal and ethical challenges of digital surveillance in countering hate speech.
items.content:
Once the scourge of antisemitism seemed confined to fringe ideologues; today it thrives online and spills into the streets of major cities. In this investigative report, Raphaël Jerusalmy reveals how digital tools are enlisted to fight back.

Mossad’s cyber-intelligence teams mine millions of social-media posts, flagging hate speech patterns and tracing them to real-world actors. Meanwhile, IoT devices—smart cameras in public spaces—feed into AI systems trained to detect antisemitic slogans on placards or graffiti.

These methods have already led to dozens of arrests, disrupting hate-networks before they can mobilize. Yet they raise thorny legal and ethical questions: How do we balance privacy rights against collective security? Who oversees the watchdogs?

Jerusalmy urges transparent oversight: parliamentary committees, independent auditors, and clear data-retention policies. If wielded responsibly, these technologies can turn the tide against hate; if misused, they risk undermining the very freedoms they aim to protect.

items.title: Israel, Europe’s Protector
items.excerpt: Those who think of arms embargos or prevent Israelis from accessing the Eurosatory show are shooting themselves in the foot. Israel protects Europe.
items.subtitle: How Israeli defense partnerships bolster Europe against external and internal threats
items.description: Raphaël Jerusalmy explores three security challenges facing Europe—geostrategic rivalries, Islamist expansionism, and rising domestic extremism—and shows how Israeli defense cooperation, from NATO collaboration to advanced missile-defense systems like Arrow-3 and the Iron Dome, serves as a critical bulwark for the continent’s safety.
items.content:
Europe faces a trifecta of security challenges: great-power competition in its periphery, the spread of Islamist militancy in neighboring regions, and the unsettling rise of home-grown extremism. In each case, Israeli-European defense ties provide vital support.

Since joining NATO’s Partnership for Peace, Israel has shared real-time intelligence on threats ranging from cyber-intrusions to terrorist cell movements. Joint exercises have honed rapid-response protocols along Europe’s southern flank.

On the technological front, systems like the Iron Dome and Arrow-3 have been demoed to European defense ministers, sparking interest in co-production and joint procurement. These shields do not merely defend Israeli skies—they offer a model for protecting major European capitals.

Jerusalmy concludes that lifting arms-embargos and deepening collaboration is not controversial—it is pragmatic. By standing with Israel, Europe fortifies its own security architecture against the dangers of tomorrow.

items.title: RTS Interview: In Absentia, Imagination Against the Shoah
items.excerpt: 30-minute radio interview about the new novel In Absentia and the importance of imagination in the face of horror.
items.subtitle: Exploring how imagination confronts historical trauma
items.description: In this 30-minute RTS Culture interview, Raphaël Jerusalmy discusses his novel *In Absentia*, delving into how fiction and imagination serve as essential tools for bearing witness to the Shoah, preserving memory, and honoring the resilience of its victims.
items.content:
In this intimate RTS Culture interview, Raphaël Jerusalmy reflects on the genesis of his novel *In Absentia*, born from a desire to give voice to stories erased by time. He explains how fiction can capture the unspoken nuances of human suffering that history books often overlook.

Jerusalmy discusses the moral responsibility of the writer: to bear witness, to honor memory, and to challenge readers to imagine the lives behind the numbers. He recounts conversations with survivors whose experiences—though unspeakable—demand to be told.

Through carefully crafted characters, the novel bridges past and present, showing how the echoes of the Shoah ripple through today’s world. Jerusalmy argues that only by engaging the imagination can we guard against collective amnesia.

Listeners learn about his research process—archival visits, survivor testimonies, and the alchemy of blending fact with narrative empathy. The interview closes on a hopeful note: that art, in its most honest form, can spark both remembrance and renewal.
